DataElement.preferredName: Melanoma Lateral Surgical Margin Surgical Margin Status LateralMelanomaMarginStatus
DataElement.preferredDefinition: A malignant, usually aggressive tumor composed of atypical, neoplastic melanocytes.  Most often, melanomas arise in the skin (cutaneous melanomas) and include the following histologic subtypes: superficial spreading melanoma, nodular melanoma, acral lentiginous melanoma, and lentigo maligna melanoma.  Cutaneous melanomas may arise from acquired or congenital melanocytic or dysplastic nevi.  Melanomas may also arise in other anatomic sites including the gastrointestinal system, eye, urinary tract, and reproductive system.  Melanomas frequently metastasize to lymph nodes, liver, lungs, and brain.:Situated at or extending to the side.:One of the criteria for assessment of the effectiveness of given surgical procedure in achieving the local control of a neoplasm and the adequacy of tumor removal. It is defined by the tissue plane through which the dissection has been done and the actual or potential neoplastic tissue which has been left outside the boundary of a resected specimen within the patient. There are four types of surgical margins: intracapsular or intralesional, marginal, wide, and radical._One of the criteria for assessment of the effectiveness of given surgical procedure in achieving the local control of a neoplasm and the adequacy of tumor removal. It is defined by the tissue plane through which the dissection has been done and the actual or potential neoplastic tissue which has been left outside the boundary of a resected specimen within the patient. There are four types of surgical margins: intracapsular or intralesional, marginal, wide, and radical.:A condition or state at a particular time._Status for absence or presence of margin

Concepts.definition: A malignant, usually aggressive tumor composed of atypical, neoplastic melanocytes. Most often, melanomas arise in the skin (cutaneous melanomas) and include the following histologic subtypes: superficial spreading melanoma, nodular melanoma, acral lentiginous melanoma, and lentigo maligna melanoma. Cutaneous melanomas may arise from acquired or congenital melanocytic or dysplastic nevi. Melanomas may also arise in other anatomic sites including the gastrointestinal system, eye, urinary tract, and reproductive system. Melanomas frequently metastasize to lymph nodes, liver, lungs, and brain.
Situated at or extending to the side.

One of the criteria for assessment of the effectiveness of given surgical procedure in achieving the local control of a neoplasm and the adequacy of tumor removal. There are four types of surgical margins: intracapsular or intralesional, marginal, wide, and radical.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Invasive Skin Melanoma Involvement Surgical Margin

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Invasive Skin Melanoma Involvement Surgical Margin
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: One of the criteria for assessment of the effectiveness of given surgical procedure in achieving the local control of a neoplasm and the adequacy of tumor removal. It is defined by the tissue plane through which the dissection has been done and the actual or potential neoplastic tissue which has been left outside the boundary of a resected specimen within the patient. There are four types of surgical margins: intracapsular or intralesional, marginal, wide, and radical.:To have a connection by participation or association or use; sharing in an activity or process.:A melanoma of the skin that is not confined to the dermal-epidermal junction, and has infiltrated the dermis.

Concepts.definition: A melanoma of the skin that is not confined to the dermal-epidermal junction, and has infiltrated the dermis.
To have a connection by participation or association or use; sharing in an activity or process.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: One of the criteria for assessment of the effectiveness of given surgical procedure in achieving the local control of a neoplasm and the adequacy of tumor removal. It is defined by the tissue plane through which the dissection has been done and the actual or potential neoplastic tissue which has been left outside the boundary of a resected specimen within the patient. There are four types of surgical margins: intracapsular or intralesional, marginal, wide, and radical.:To have a connection by participation or association or use; sharing in an activity or process.:A melanoma of the skin characterized by the presence of melanoma cells in the dermal-epidermal junction only, without infiltration of the papillary or reticular dermis.

Concepts.longName: Stage 0 Cutaneous Melanoma AJCC v6 and v7
Concepts.definition: Stage 0 includes: Tis, N0, M0.  Tis: Melanoma in situ.  N0: No regional lymph node metastases.  M0: No detectable evidence of distant metastases. (from AJCC 6th and 7th Eds.)
To have a connection by participation or association or use; sharing in an activity or process.
